Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Negotiation and Communication Skills for Female Engineers and Faculty; Seattle, Washington

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support a workshop to improve negotiation and communication skills for female professionals attending the 2017 American Control Conference, a premier scientific and engineering conference dedicated to the advancement of control theory and practice. The intended outcome of the workshop is to foster the professional growth of female mathematicians, scientists, and engineers working, so that their contributions are fully integrated into the advancement of this field.

The purpose of this workshop is mentoring the new generation of scientists with the focus on negotiation and communication skills. The workshop is an initiative of the "Women in Control" (WiC) and COACh programs. The half-day workshop will incorporate case studies and role-playing exercises in order to allow early-career academics to improve their communication skills.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A half day workshop was organized on May 23 2017 as part of the American control conference (ACC 2017). 

The purpose of this workshop was mentoring of new generation of female scientist and engineers with the focus on negotiation and communication skills. Specifically, it targeted Systems and Control community.

 

This workshop provided participants with hands on professional negotiation skills and its multi-faceted approach.

The whole group worked on a case that was taken directly from the group and had the opportunity to role play the case to a successful outcome.  The intended outcome was professional growth, development of individual success through teamwork. Second part of the workshop focused on helping professionals be more effective when leading or participating in discussions, meetings, or group negotiations. They learned about strategic rather than reactive behaviors and effective speaking voices, while tuning out stress and tension, to make yourself be heard. Participants were introduced to performance techniques that people in the theater and in leadership training understand about how to be effective (body language and non-verbals).

 

This workshop improved presentation performance, negotiation and communication skills of female scientist which are still minority in the field.

It is expected that improvement of these skills will have positive effect on their visibility and performance in research, teaching, leadership, which are necessary and should lead to more successful academic or industrial professional carrier.

The most important outcomes were:

- Using a strong voice and the body language that project confidence.

- Improving their skills in handling an unpleasant and/or conflicting situation.

- Mastering basic rules of negotiations such as

  • Importance of preparation before the meeting
  • Entering meeting with the purpose and keeping the focus on its objectives.
  • Finding a common ground.
  • Not taking things personally
  • Practice asking for more!
